ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Re: Alternative crossover technique
ygData.msgSnippet: ... I agree with what you re saying here, but consider this. We have a NEAT genome that describes a network which we can break down into seperate sub-networks,

Kenneth Stanley wrote:

>In the usual GA view of evolution, the issue of genes that are 
>functionally dependent being inherited together seems to be 
>considered significant.  However, I question whether this is really 
>a major problem in nature or NEAT?  Since crossover for the most 
>part takes place in a single species, and two organisms in the same 
>species more or less have the same set of genes, the issue of 
>different building blocks being broken apart from the parents to the 
>offspring seems overblown.  Of course, if a duck mated with a pig, 
>it would be a huge problem to make sure the duck genes largely stuck 
>together.  However, why is this such a concern when a duck mates 
>with a duck?
>
>  
>
I agree with what you're saying here, but consider this. We have a NEAT 
genome that describes a network which we can break down into seperate 
sub-networks, each of which is useful in it's own right. How do we allow 
NEAT to exchange whole sub-networks and try out combinations unless we 
somehow group genes within the genome. Nature groups genes by placing 
them close together in the genome, and because crossover works on chunks 
of connected genes, those that are close together will most likely 
remain together after crossover - and not be split up.

On the other hand, the two parent genomes are so closely matched that 
the alternative sequence we get from the other parent is almost the 
same, which takes us back to your point. Yeh, more thinking required on 
this one.

Colin.
